learning_outcomes.description: Identifies the socio-economic, political, cultural and physical environmental factors that contribute to health outcomes for individuals and communities. (AHI01)
Cares for individuals from diverse populations and is committed to achieving equity in healthcare outcomes. (AHI02)
Explains, identifies, and applies public health methods including health screening and prevention approaches and incorporates prevention and early detection equitably into clinical practice. (AHI03)
Demonstrates commitment to healthcare sustainability and advocacy for climate change mitigation and adaptation. (AHI04)

Describes the factors that contribute to the health and wellbeing of specific populations including Indigenous Australians and other culturally and linguistically diverse groups and approaches to helping to address these factors. (AHI05)

Demonstrates ability to be a steward for the healthcare system through the efficient and equitable allocation of healthcare resources to meet individual community and national health needs, while enhancing quality and safety. (AHI06)
Describes global health issues and their relevance to healthcare delivery. (AHI07)
Explains and demonstrates how health informatics and health technology can be used in clinical practice to improve patient outcomes and experiences. (AHI08)
Describes the challenges and opportunities in health and healthcare in rural and remote areas. (AHI09)
Applies biological, clinical, social, and behavioural sciences in healthcare. (CTSS01)
Accesses, critically appraises and applies health data and evidence from medical and scientific literature. (CTSS02)
Applies scientific methods to generate and translate knowledge that improves the quality and safety of healthcare. (CTSS03)

Describes Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander knowledges of wellbeing and models of health care, including community and sociocultural strengths, as well as best practice approaches that lead to positive health and wellbeing outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander communities. (CTSS04)
Demonstrates professional and ethical scholarship, considering alternative perspectives and respectfully challenging beliefs and assumptions. (CTSS05)
Demonstrates agility, adaptability and openness to change. (DLE01)
Supports and contributes to the learning of others. (DLE02)
Is a self-regulated learner that reflects on their own professional practice seeks input from others and implements actions as part of continuous learning. (DLE03)
Manages time and prioritises workload. (DLE04)
Communicates with clarity and sensitivity in all interactions. (KCP01)
Demonstrates kindness and compassion to others (KCP02)
Takes a whole of person, compassionate approach to clinical care across the life course and in a range of settings. (KCP03)
Recognises and safeguards vulnerable patients. (KCP04)
Acts in accordance with the fundamental ethical and legal requirements of health professionals. (KCP05)
Demonstrates professionalism and leadership in healthcare (KCP06)
Empowers patients to manage their own health and wellbeing according to individual preferences and capabilities. (KCP07)
Collaborates effectively as a member of the health care team in the provision of whole person care, health-related education and research. (PTP01)
Works effectively as a member of learning, scholarly and research groups, and healthcare teams. (PTP02)
Partners effectively with a diverse range of people to achieve a healthcare system which accomplishes whole person care. (PTP03)
Relates respectfully to patients, colleagues, healthcare team members and others, is mindful of sociocultural diversity and open to different views and perspectives. (PTP04)
Maintains appropriate student, academic, professional and therapeutic relationships. (PTP05)
Contributes to a positive, supportive and collegiate workplace and team culture. (PTP06)
Communicates effectively and with cultural safety. (SEC01)
Integrates information from multiple sources, including a patient history, clinical examination, and the results of appropriately selected investigations. (SEC02)
Demonstrates safe and effective clinical judgement based on the available evidence and recognises one’s own limitations of practice and seek support. (SEC03)
Performs a range of procedural skills appropriate to the level of a graduating doctor. (SEC04)
Demonstrates ability to prescribe medications and administer other therapeutic agents safely effectively and economically using up to date evidence. (SEC05)
Devises a management plan in collaboration with the patient and their family/carers that prioritises the patient’s goals of care. (SEC06)
Recognises and assesses deteriorating and critically unwell patients who require immediate care. Implements immediate emergency and life supporting care. (SEC07)
Effectively manages patients with multiple comorbidities. (SEC08)

Demonstrates understanding of the principles of care for patients preparing for their future care or at the end of their lives with consideration of physical comfort, psychosocial support for the patient and their family/carers including when not to intervene. (SEC09)
Contributes to clinical care across patients’ life course. (SEC10)
Is clear, accurate and appropriate with respect to written and / or electronic documentation. (SEC11)
Actively monitors and addresses personal wellbeing, fatigue, health and safety to support self-care and patient care. (SEC12)

assessments.due_date:
CAT 9: Week of 27/04/2026

CAT 10: Week of 31/08/2026

CAT 11: End of Year Examination Week
assessments.task_description:
Through the year, you will complete a sequence of three (3) invigilated computer delivered MCQ tests. These tests will occur simultaneously across the learning communities. The content of each test with correspond to your immersion sequence to ensure the assessment of knowledge aligns with your learning experiences. 

CAT 9 (90 mins): 60 MCQ items (65-75% MCQ related to Immersion; 15-20% MCQ common questions related to Integrated Concept Tutorials and prior learning, 10-15% MCQ related to prior learning)

CAT 10 (90 mins): 60 MCQ items (65-75% MCQ related to Immersion; 15-20% MCQ common questions related to Integrated Concept Tutorials and prior learning, 10-15% MCQ related to prior learning)

CAT 11 (120 mins): 80 MCQ items (65-75% MCQ related to Immersion; 15-20% MCQ common questions related to Integrated Concept Tutorials and prior learning, 10-15% MCQ related to prior learning)

After each CAT assessment, you will receive feedback that includes:

  • Your overall score and number of questions correct compared to the minimum pass standard
  • Performance analysis by immersion topics
  • Performance breakdown across different question categories

This structured feedback is designed to help you identify areas of strength and those needing further development as you progress through your clinical rotations.

Criteria & Marking:

Your scores will accumulate across the THREE (3) CATs. The percentage contribution of each CAT to the sequence cumulative total score is as follows:

  • CAT 9 contributes to 30% of the total CAT score, 
  • CAT 10 contributes 30% of the total CAT score, and
  • CAT 11 contributes 40% of the total CAT score. 

The score boundaries defining ‘Indeterminate’ (and therefore clearly satisfactory and clearly not satisfactory) will be established using an appropriate standard-setting methodology. The upper boundary for indeterminate range is defined as derived standard score + 1 x standard error of measurement (SEM, calculated from assessment data). The lower boundary of the indeterminate range is defined as derived standard score - 3 x SEM.

Further information on the CAT passing standard and its contribution to the progression decision at the end of the year is found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ
assessments.submission_guidelines: May be held on a Saturday
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: KNOWLEDGE & PROFESSIONALISM AND LEADERSHIP : Scholarly Project
assessments.mode: Activity/ Performance, Oral, Product/ Artefact/ Multimedia, Written
assessments.category: Paper/ Report/ Annotation, Participation/ Student contribution, Performance, Practical/ Demonstration, Presentation, Project, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
You will have the opportunity to work with a group of 4-5 of your peers on a scholarly project, for 2 hours each week across the 35 weeks of Year 3. The project will be undertaken alongside your clinical immersions throughout the year. This project provides an opportunity to work collaboratively on a group initiative while developing and applying the scholarly inquiry skills essential to medical practice.

The scholarly project outcomes build on the learning experiences in Year 1 and 2, particularly research and teamwork skills, including:      

  • understanding of the fundamentals of the research process through the Introduction to Research for Clinicians self-directed module, and completion of the longitudinal teaching program,
  • applying biomedical research to understand issues in healthcare and clinical practice,  
  • understanding the principles of evidence-informed medicine and critical appraisal of literature,
  • understanding and demonstrating the steps involved in performing a systematic literature review,
  • developing and enhancing skills in teamwork and self-directed learning skills, and
  • further developing the ability to give and receive peer feedback and engage with self-reflection


The Scholarly Project is structured around five milestone assessments that guide your progress throughout the year.

  • Milestone 1: Confirmation of group members, allocated group leader, the project title, supervision arrangements, and group contract completion acknowledgment in MS Forms
  • Milestone 2: Submission of the group project proposal by group leader via Turnitin on Learn.UQ. This will be graded against a rubric by your supervisor.
  • Milestone 3: Submission of an individual supervisor Mid-project report via ePAD and Mid-project self+peer review reports via BuddyCheck in Learn.UQ.
  • Milestone 4: Submission of a group oral poster presentation by group leader via Turnitin on Learn.UQ.
  • Milestone 5: Has 2 components : 1. Submission of a group written report by group leader via Turnitin on Learn.UQ, and 2. Submission of an individual supervisor End-project report via ePAD and End-project self+peer review reports via BuddyCheck in Learn.UQ.


These milestones provide a scaffolded approach to project development, ensuring regular engagement with your group and supervisor(s). Each milestone focuses on a key stage of the research process - beginning with a formal project agreement, followed by the development of a project proposal, a mid-year review, and culminating in two major scholarly outputs : a group oral presentation and a formal written report. Supervisor and peer feedback are integrated at each stage to support continuous improvement and successful completion of your project.

Further information can be found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ.


Criteria & Marking:

If the group oral presentation is not completed with all individuals present, an alternative task will be arranged for those individuals unable to attend. If the presentation is not at/above or well above standard a further presentation, after feedback with be arranged.

If the written report is not at standard when graded against a rubric by a project supervisor, further submission(s) will be possible after feedback. Completion of the Written Report At/Above or Well Above standard is required for progression. 

The Scholarly Project Report will be marked against the relevant rubrics and used to inform Knowledge progression decision. The Scholarly Project compliance requirements for group submission, peer review and peer self-review documents, and group presentation will be marked against a rubric and be used to inform Professionalism and Leadership progression decision. Rubrics can be found on Learn.UQ
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: CLINICAL SKILLS : Longitudinal Immersion Assessments - Mini- CEX
assessments.due_date: 5pm, Friday (AEST): Last week of each clinical immersion
assessments.category: Notebook/ Logbook, Performance, Placement, Practical/ Demonstration
assessments.task_description:
During each immersion, you will undertake several assessments based on observed patient encounters and workplace-based activities. Some observed workplace-based activities may occur in simulated environments (e.g. during immersion tutorials), as indicated in each immersion outline on Learn.UQ

The Mini-CEX include:

  • Mini-CEx (history)
  • Mini-CEx (examination)
  • Mini-CEx (patient education/explanation)
  • Mini-CEx (history and examination)
  • Mini-CEx (prescribing and therapeutic reasoning)
  • Mini-CEx (reasoning for investigations)
  • Mini-CEx (clinical handover and documentation)
  • Mini-CEx (recognising the acutely unwell or deteriorating patient).


In each of these activities, the assessor will ask you to discuss and/or demonstrate aspects of care to the patient context. This activity will be customised according to the clinical immersion and may occur in an authentic or simulated environment.

Further information can be found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submitted electronically using the UQ MyProgress platform.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: KNOWLEDGE & CLINICAL SKILLS : Longitudinal Immersion Assessments - Patient Focused Assessment (PFA)
assessments.due_date:
Medicine: Week 7 or 8 of Immersion

Mental Health: Week 8 tutorial for GBCS and OCS students. For RCS students, to be completed Week 8 of any immersion once mental health tutorials have been completed.

Child and Adolescent Health and Wellbeing: Week 8 of Immersion

Surgery: Week 6 or 8 of Immersion

Obstetrics and Gynaecology: Week 8 of Immersion
assessments.task_description:
In each immersion, except for the rural immersion, you will have a Patient Focused Assessment (PFA). The PFAs are based on patient(s) seen by you, or a clinical scenario provided to you (with or without a standardised patient). You will engage in an in-depth discussion with an assessor(s). You may present and/or discuss the patient with the assessor, responding to structured questions from the assessor concerning diagnostic, investigative and therapeutic reasoning, patient management and/or whole person approach to care. Some PFAs (e.g., in Mental Health Immersion) will require a written response to discuss the same aspects of patient care.

  • Medicine: Long Case and Standardised Clinical Scenario
  • Mental Health: Written task based on patient case
  • Child and Adolescent Health and Wellbeing: Case discussion
  • Surgery: Clinical Case Presentation
  • Obstetrics and Gynaecology: Structured Clinical Assessment

Specific information about the delivery format and logistics for each immersion PFA can be found on Learn.UQ .
assessments.submission_guidelines: Refer to individual clinical immersion folder in Learn.UQ for further submission instructions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date: 66% i.e. 50 procedures to have been completed (with the DOPS at standard) by end of immersion 5
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Performance, Placement, Practical/ Demonstration
assessments.task_description:
You will complete your Clinical Skills Passport comprised of COPS and DOPS. DOPS procedures should be completed "at standard". Completion of four specific skills (perineal suturing, colposcopy, IUCD insertion and vaginal delivery) is highly recommended during the Obstetrics and Gynaecology immersion as these skills may be difficult to obtain in other immersions.

For a full list of Clinical Skills Passport activities, please refer to Learn.UQ

This assessment contribute to Waypoints, Review Panel and Progression Decision.

  • 20% i.e. 15 procedures to have been completed (with the DOPS at standard) by Review Panel 1 at end of immersion 2
  • 50% i.e. 38 procedures to have been completed (with the DOPS at standard) by Review Panel 2 at end of immersion 4
  • 66% i.e. 50 procedures to have been completed (with the DOPS at standard) by Progress Decision Committee at end of immersion 5


Completion of remaining procedures for the Clinical Skills Passport to 100% of total is required by completion of the fourth term in Year 4.

Further information on the Clinical skills passport and the progression decision at end of year can be found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Clinical Skills Passport is submitted electronically using the UQ MyProgress Platform
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: KNOWLEDGE & CLINICAL SKILLS & PROFESSIONALISM AND LEADERSHIP : Longitudinal Immersion Assessments - Clinical Supervisor Reports
assessments.due_date: 5pm, Friday (AEST): Last week of each clinical immersion
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Performance, Placement, Practical/ Demonstration, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
You will have 5 Immersion Clinical Supervisor Reports, one for each of your 8-week immersions. The Immersion Clinical Supervisor Report is completed by a nominated supervisor for you at the end of each immersion. The supervisor will have observed you during your immersion time, and/or will gather input as appropriate from other supervising clinicians and members of the unit, ward, clinic, practice or team. The focus is on aspects of patient care, collaborative practice and professionalism, and completion of clinical immersion specific clinical requirements (e.g. attendance at specific clinics and in various learning environments as detailed in the core learning experiences for each immersion). Each of these events will include a discussion to allow you to seek feedback on aspects of your performance. There will be a brief written summary provided by the nominated supervisor. The initial discussion of your clinical immersion learning plan will be confirmed.

Further information can be found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Submitted electronically using the UQ MyProgress platform.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: PROFESSIONALISM AND LEADERSHIP : Professional Development Portfolio
assessments.due_date:
Ongoing - multiple submission dates (Immersion-specific).

Due by 5pm Friday 6 November 2026 (AEST).
assessments.category: Participation/ Student contribution, Performance, Placement, Portfolio, Reflection
assessments.task_description:
The suite of components forming the Professional Development Portfolio are derived from learning activities completed across the academic year to demonstrate your engagement in education, professional development, quality improvement and assurance activities for personal and peer benefit, as well as your dedication to professional standards as a developing medical practitioner. Digital records will provide evidence of your longitudinal participation and engagement in learning experiences and highlight your professional growth, contributions to your learning community, and your active role in feedback processes with tutors, clinical supervisors, and peers.

The required tasks contributing to the digital records associated with this assessment are outlined below:

  • 5 Clinical Immersion learning plans, uploaded at the commencement of each immersion
  • 5 Clinical insights from patient care, one completed per immersion
  • Clinical Pharmacology modules, completed, usually during the Medicine Immersion
  • Evidence of engagement with PCEP assessment in the Child and Adolescents Health and Wellbeing Immersion
  • Evidence of engagement with 2 x Case-Based discussions for students who undertake the Rural Immersion


The quality of your learning plans and reflections are critical to the development of your portfolio, as these evidence your growth in line with the 6 MD program themes.

Criteria & Marking:

Your compliance with uploading the minimum requirements of the Professional Development Portfolio (records on MyProgress ePAD) will be used to inform Clinical Skills and Professionalism & Leadership progression decisions. There is no Marginal Fail for the Professional Development Portfolio.

Further information can be found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Most components within this assessment are submitted electronically using the UQ MyProgress platform.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: End of the year (exact date to be confirmed)
assessments.category: Performance, Practical/ Demonstration, Role play/ Simulation
assessments.task_description:
At the end of Year 3 there will be a whole cohort OSCE, which will provide information on your consultation skills of history, examination, explanation/planning, communication, clinical reasoning, cultural capability and safety and professional conduct. The 10 station OSCE will be administered across multiple sites.

Feedback will be provided after the OSCE. This will include examiner feedback and performance relative to readiness to progress on individual stations.

Criteria & Marking:

To meet the progression requirements for the OSCE you must:

  1. Achieve an overall score (sum of station scores) equal to or above the overall standard score (sum of station standard scores)
  2. Achieve station score equal to or above station standard score for 7 or more stations

For each station the score equivalent to standard to progress to year 4 (standard score) will be determined using appropriate standard setting methodology.

Students who do not meet the standard for the OSCE will be deemed Marginal Fail for the OSCE component. Student who receive a Marginal Fail are eligible to apply for a supplementary assessment. The supplementary assessment will be an OSCE of the same number and length of stations and overall blueprint, and progression requirements.

Further information can be found in the MEDI7300 Course Guide on Learn.UQ.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
Integrated Concept Tutorials

You will attend a weekly whole cohort virtual integrated concept tutorial. These tutorials will integrate learning across specialities and between disciplines and highlight the use of the multidisciplinary team in patient care. In addition, this tutorial series will help highlight and integrate the six core curriculum themes through the year.

Queensland: Thursday 12:30pm-1:30pm

Ochsner: Monday 2:00pm-4:00pm

The full Integrated Concept Tutorial timetable can be found on Learn.UQ .

Students should prioritise attendance at ICT topics live when the topic aligns with their current immersion to gain most benefit, including being able to engage with case discussion, QnA and MCQ/CAT question practice.

learning_activities.topic:
Scholarly Project

Engagement with scholarly project – undertaking group project activity and working with peers to generate an oral presentation and formal written project report over 35 weeks of Year 3. Nominally 2 hours each week should be committed to work on the scholarly project.


Learning outcomes: L11, L12, L14, L16, L17, L27

Nominally 2 hours each week should be committed to work on the scholarly project.

learning_activities.topic:
Professional Development Portfolio

As in MEDI7100 and MEDI7200, you will curate evidence of your progression towards the MEDI7300 learning outcomes and MD Program Themes.

  • Clinical Immersion learning plans
  • Clinical insights from patient care
  • Clinical Pharmacology modules (Medicine immersion)
  • PCEP assessment (Child and Adolescents Health and Wellbeing immersion)
  • Case-Based discussions (Rural immersion)
  • Clinical Skills Passport
